\newpage\section{Snake Lemmas}

\subsection{\texorpdfstring{$3 \times 3$}{PDFstring} Lemmas}

Our $3 \times 3$-lemmas begin with two conflations with either two of the morphisms in $(i_1, i_2, i_3)$

\begin{equation}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}
	{A_1} & {A_2} & {A_3} & {\,} \\
	{B_1} & {B_2} & {B_3} & {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{i_2}", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{i_3}", dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}

\begin{example}\label{ex:3x3-fail}
	Let $f$ be any morphism in the category. Let $i_1 = 0$ and $i_2 = \binom 1f$ be $\mathbb E$-inflations in the following diagram.
\begin{equation}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	0 \& X \& X \& {\, } \\
	X \& {X \oplus Y} \& Y \& {\, }
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["0"', from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{1_X}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\binom 1f}"', from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["f"', dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\binom 10}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{(0,1)}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}
	One must have $i_3 = f$. This diagram fails to be a $3 \times 3$-diagram.
\end{example}

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:3x3-lemma}
	Suppose we have conflations realising $\delta_A$, $\delta_B$, $\varepsilon_1$ and $\varepsilon_3$ in the following diagram:
	\begin{equation}\label{eq:3x3-mid}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}
	{A_1} & {A_2} & {A_3} & {\,} \\
	{B_1} & {B_2} & {B_3} & {\,} \\
	{C_1} & {C_2} & {C_3} & {\,} \\
	{\,} & {\,} & {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{i_2}", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{i_3}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{p_1}", from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{p_2}", dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{p_3}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_C}", dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _1}", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["{g_C}", dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _2}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_C}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _3}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd},
	\end{equation}
	such that $(i_3)^\ast \delta_B = (i_1)_\ast \delta_A$. Then there is a way to complete the diagram to a $3 \times 3$-diagram.
	\begin{proof}
		By \cref{thm:hs-morphism}, we take $i_2$ such that $(i_1;i_2;i_3)$ is homotopic:
		\begin{equation}\label{eq:pf-3x3-0}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}
	{A_1} & {A_2} & {A_3} & {\,} \\
	{B_1} & E & {A_3} & {\,} \\
	{B_1} & {B_2} & {B_3} & {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{j_1}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["s", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["t", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{j_2}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["\kappa", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{i_3}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd},
		\end{equation}
		We denote $\kappa = 
(i_1)_\ast \delta_A = (i_3)^\ast \delta_B$. The construction of $j_1$ and $j_2$ are due to \cref{prop:strict-et4-2-h,prop:po-1-h}:
\begin{equation}\label{eq:pf-3x3-1}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}
	{A_1} & {A_2} & {A_3} & {\,} & {B_1} & E & {A_3} & {\,} \\
	{B_1} & E & {A_3} & {\,} & {B_1} & {B_2} & {B_3} & {\,} \\
	{C_1} & {C_1} && {\,} && {C_3} & {C_3} \\
	{\,} & {\,} &&&& {\, } & {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{j_1}", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["s", from=1-5, to=1-6]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["t", from=1-6, to=1-7]
	\arrow["{j_2}", dashed, from=1-6, to=2-6]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["\kappa", dashed, from=1-7, to=1-8]
	\arrow["{i_3}", from=1-7, to=2-7]
	\arrow["s", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{p_1}", from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["t", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["q", dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\kappa", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=2-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["{p_3 g_B}", dashed, from=2-6, to=3-6]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=2-7, to=2-8]
	\arrow["{p_3}", from=2-7, to=3-7]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _1}", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-2, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{(f_A)_\ast \varepsilon _1}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-6, to=3-7]
	\arrow["\theta", dashed, from=3-6, to=4-6]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _3}", dashed, from=3-7, to=4-7]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}
We construct $\varepsilon_2$ and $\delta_C$ by ET4, 
\begin{equation}\label{eq:pf-3x3-2}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}
	{A_2} & {A_2} \\
	E & {B_2} & {C_3} & {\, } \\
	{C_1} & {C_2} & {C_3} & {\,} \\
	{\,} & {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{j_1}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{i_2}", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{j_2}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["q", from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{p_3 g_B}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{p_2}", dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\theta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_C}", dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{(f_A)_\ast \varepsilon _1}", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["{g_C}", dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _2}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_C}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}
It remains to verify \cref{eq:3x3-mid} is a $3\times 3$-diagram under the above construction.
\begin{enumerate}
	\item ($f_Bi_1 = i_2f_A$). $i_2f_A \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-2}}} j_2j_1 f_A  \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-0}}} f_Bi_1$.
	\item ($g_Bi_2 = i_3g_A$). $g_Bi_2 \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-2}}} g_B j_2j_1 \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-1}}} i_3tj_1\xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-0}}}i_3g_A$.
	\item ($f_Cp_1 = p_2f_B$). $f_Cp_1 \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-1}}} f_Cqs\xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-2}}} p_2j_2s\xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-0}}} p_2f_B$.
	\item ($g_Cp_2 = p_3g_B$). $g_Cp_2 \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-2}}} p_3g_B$.
	\item ($(i_1)_\ast\delta_A = (i_3)^\ast\delta_B$). We presuppose this identity.
	\item ($(p_1)_\ast\delta_B = (p_3)^\ast\delta_C$). $(p_1)_\ast\delta_B \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-1}}} q_\ast s_\ast\delta_B \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-2}}} q_\ast (p_3)^\ast\theta = (p_3)^\ast q_\ast \theta \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-2}}} (p_3)^\ast\delta_C$.
	\item ($(f_A)_\ast\varepsilon_1 = (f_C)^\ast \varepsilon_2$). $(f_A)_\ast\varepsilon_1 \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-2}}} (f_C)^\ast \varepsilon_2$.
	\item ($(g_A)_\ast\varepsilon_2 = (g_C)^\ast \varepsilon_3$). $(g_A)_\ast\varepsilon_2 \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-0}}} t_\ast (j_1)_\ast \varepsilon_2 \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-2}}} t_\ast (g_C)^\ast \theta = (g_C)^\ast t_\ast \theta \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:pf-3x3-1}}} (g_C)^\ast \varepsilon_3$.
\end{enumerate}
	\end{proof}
\end{theorem}

\begin{corollary}\label{cor:3x3-lemma-inflation}
	Let $\alpha$, $\beta$ and $\gamma$ be all inflations (or dually, all deflations) such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of conflations. Then it extends to a $3\times 3$-diagram.
	\begin{proof}
		There is a way to construct \cref{eq:pf-3x3-0}. Now \cref{thm:3x3-lemma} completes the proof.
	\end{proof}
\end{corollary}

\begin{corollary}
	Let $\alpha$, $\beta$ and $\gamma$ be all inflations (or dually, all deflations) such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a morphism of conflations. There is a way to find $(\alpha';\beta;\gamma)$, $(\alpha;\beta';\gamma)$ and $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma')$ which completes to $3 \times 3$ diagram.
	\begin{proof}
		By \cref{thm:hs-morphism,cor:3x3-lemma-inflation}, we are done.
	\end{proof}
\end{corollary}

\begin{proposition}\label{prop:deflation-retract}
	Suppose we have the commutative diagram of conflations:
	\begin{equation}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}
	{A_1} & {A_2} & {A_3} & {\,} \\
	{B_1} & {B_2} & {B_3} & {\,} \\
	& {C_2} & {C_3} \\
	& {\,} & {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{i_2}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["{i_3}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{p_2}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{p_3}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{g_C}", dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _2}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon _3}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation}
	Then there exists $i_1$ and $p_3$ such that the above diagram commutes, and
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item $i_1$ is a retract of some inflation, $p_3$ is a retract of some deflation,
		\item $(i_1;i_2;i_3)$ and $(g_A;g_B;g_C)$ are homotopic morphisms of conflations.
	\end{enumerate}
	\begin{proof}
		We construct $i_1$ as follows. By \cref{lem:hs-1g?}, we can find an inflation $j_2$ such that $(1_{B_1};j_2;i_3)$ is a homotopy morphism of conflations. We then construct $j_1$ by \cref{prop:weak}, and $i_1$ by \cref{lem:hs-?g1}.
		\begin{equation}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}
	{A_1} & {A_2} & {A_3} & {\,} \\
	{B_1} & E & {A_3} & {\, } \\
	{B_1} & {B_2} & {B_3} & {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_1}", dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{j_1}", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{i_2}"'{pos=0.7}, curve={height=12pt}, from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow[from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{j_2}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{(i_3)^\ast \delta_B}", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{i_3}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		Here $j_1$ is a retract of some inflation by \cref{prop:comp-infldefl}, and $i_1$ is also a retract of some inflation by \cref{lem:hs-retract}. Dually, we can construct $p_3$ which is a retract of some deflation. The rest is clear.
	\end{proof}
\end{proposition}

\begin{remark}
	Under WIC condition, \cref{prop:deflation-retract} completes to a $3 \times 3$-diagram.
\end{remark}

\begin{theorem}
	We use $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ to denote a morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item For any morphism $\gamma$, there are $\mathbb E$-inflations $\alpha$ and $\beta$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item If $\alpha$ and $\gamma$ are $\mathbb E$-inflations, then there is a way to find some $\mathbb E$-inflation $\beta$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item If $\beta$ and $\gamma$ are $\mathbb E$-inflations, then there is a way to find some retract of $\mathbb E$-inflation $\alpha$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item If $\alpha$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation and $\beta$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation, then there is a way to find some $\mathbb E$-deflation $\gamma$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item For any morphism $\beta$, there is a way to find some $\mathbb E$-inflation $\alpha$ and some $\mathbb E$-deflation $\gamma$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item If $\beta$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation and $\gamma$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation, then there is a way to find some $\mathbb E$-inflation $\alpha$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item If $\alpha$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation and $\beta$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, then there is a way to find some retract of $\mathbb E$-inflation $\gamma$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item If $\beta$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation and $\gamma$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation, then there is a way to find some retract of $\mathbb E$-deflation $\gamma$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item If $\alpha$ and $\gamma$ are $\mathbb E$-deflations, then there is a way to find some retract of $\mathbb E$-deflation $\gamma$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item If $\alpha$ and $\gamma$ are $\mathbb E$-deflations, then there is a way to find some $\mathbb E$-deflation $\beta$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
		\item For any morphism $\alpha$, there are $\mathbb E$-deflations $\beta$ and $\gamma$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations.
	\end{enumerate}
	Note that the final three statements are duals of the first three statements.
	\begin{proof}
		\textit{1.} See \cref{ex:3x3-fail}. \textit{2.} See \cref{thm:3x3-lemma}. \textit{3.} See \cref{prop:deflation-retract}. 
		
		\textit{4.} We construct $\overline {\alpha}$ by \cref{lem:hs-f?1}, and $\overline \gamma$ by \cref{prop:weak}. Here $\overline \gamma$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation by \cref{prop:comp-infldefl}. We then construct $\gamma$ by \cref{lem:hs-1g?}, which is an $\mathbb E$-deflation by \cref{thm:hs-infdef}.
		\begin{equation}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{A_1} \& {A_2} \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& E \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& {B_2} \& {B_3} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\overline {\alpha}}"', from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.2}, curve={height=-12pt}, from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow[from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\overline {\gamma}}"', dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", dashed, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		This complete the proof.

		\textit{5.} For any $\beta : M \to N$, we can find a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations:
		\begin{equation}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	0 \& M \& M \& {\,} \\
	N \& {M \oplus N} \& M \& {\,} \\
	N \& N \& 0 \& {\,}
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{1_M}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\binom 1 0}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\binom 01}"', from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{(1,0)}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{(\beta,1)}"', from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{1_N}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow[from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		Note that all $\square$ correspond to extension element $0$.

		\textit{6.} We construct $\overline \gamma$ by \cref{lem:hs-1?h}, and $\overline \alpha$ by \cref{prop:weak}. Here $\overline \alpha$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation by \cref{prop:comp-infldefl}. We then construct $\alpha$ by \cref{lem:hs-?g1}, which is an $\mathbb E$-inflation by \cref{thm:hs-infdef}.
		\begin{equation}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{A_1} \& {A_2} \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& E \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& {B_2} \& {B_3} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\overline {\alpha}}"', dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.2}, curve={height=-12pt}, from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow[from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\overline {\gamma}}"', from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		This complete the proof.

		\textit{7.} We construct $\overline \alpha$ by \cref{lem:hs-1?h}, and $\overline \gamma$ by \cref{prop:weak}. Here $\overline \gamma$ is a retract of some $\mathbb E$-inflation by \cref{prop:comp-infldefl}. We then construct $\gamma$ by \cref{lem:hs-?g1}, which is a retract of some $\mathbb E$-inflation by \cref{thm:hs-retract}.
		\begin{equation}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{A_1} \& {A_2} \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& E \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& {B_2} \& {B_3} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\overline {\alpha}}"', from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.2}, curve={height=-12pt}, from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow[from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\overline {\gamma}}"', dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", dashed, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		This complete the proof.

		\textit{8.} We construct $\overline \gamma$ by \cref{lem:hs-1?h}, and $\overline \alpha$ by \cref{prop:weak}. Here $\overline \alpha$ is a retract of some $\mathbb E$-deflation by \cref{prop:comp-infldefl}. We then construct $\alpha$ by \cref{lem:hs-?g1}, which is a retract of some $\mathbb E$-deflation by \cref{thm:hs-retract}.
		\begin{equation}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{A_1} \& {A_2} \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& E \& {A_3} \& {\,} \\
	{B_1} \& {B_2} \& {B_3} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{f_A}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\alpha", dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{g_A}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\overline {\alpha}}"', dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.2}, curve={height=-12pt}, from=1-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\delta_A}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow[from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\overline {\gamma}}"', from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{f_B}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{g_B}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_B}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		This complete the proof.

		\textit{9.}, \textit{10.} and \textit{11.} are dual to \textit{1.}, \textit{2.} and \textit{3.} respectively.
	\end{proof}
\end{theorem}

\subsection{Morphisms that are both \texorpdfstring{$\mathbb E$}{PDFstring}-inflations and \texorpdfstring{$\mathbb E$}{PDFstring}-deflations}

We construct various of snake lemmas in the forthcoming sections. The main obstacle is to extend $\mathbb E$-conflations to $\geq 3$ terms. Unlike admissible morphisms in exact categories (\textbf{Definition 8.1.}, \cite{buhlerExactCategories2010a}), it is somehow difficult to decompose a morphism into an $\mathbb E$-inflation followed by an $\mathbb E$-deflation in extriangulated categories in a unique way. Thus we focus on morphisms that are both inflations and deflations (\cref{def:slr}).

\begin{notation}
	Let $S$ be the collection of morphisms that are both $\mathbb E$-inflations and $\mathbb E$-deflations.
\end{notation}

\begin{remark}
	In an exact category, $S$ is the collection of isomorphisms. In a triangulated category, $S$ is the collection of all morphisms. By \cref{prop:s-2-out-of-3}, $S$ contains all isomorphisms and closed under compositions.
\end{remark}

	\begin{proposition}\label{prop:hs-inde-ef}
		Suppose we have a homotopic square between two $\mathbb E$-conflations:
		\begin{equation}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	K \& X \& Y \& {\,} \\
	K \& A \& B \& {\,}
	\arrow["i", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["f"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["u", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\boxed{\scriptstyle i_\ast \varepsilon}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["v", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["j", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
		\end{equation}
		If and only $f$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation ($\mathbb E$-deflation), then is $g$.
		
		If $f$ is both an $\mathbb E$-inflation and an $\mathbb E$-deflation, there is some $\mathbb E$-conflation $(u;v;1_C)$
		\begin{equation}\label{eq:hs-inde-ef-2}
			% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	K \& X \& Y \& C \& {\,} \\
	K \& A \& B \& C \& {\,}
	\arrow["i", dashed, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["f", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["u", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\boxed{\scriptstyle q^\ast\eta}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["p", from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["v", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\eta", dashed, from=1-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["j", dashed, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["q", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\kappa", dashed, from=2-4, to=2-5]
\end{tikzcd},
		\end{equation}
		such that $i_\ast \varepsilon = - q^\ast \eta$.
		\begin{proof}
			By \cref{thm:hs-infdef}, if and only $f$ is an $\mathbb E$-inflation ($\mathbb E$-deflation), then is $g$. When $f$ and $g$ are $\mathbb E$-inflations, we take an $\mathbb E$-conflation $K \to 0 \to FK \overset{\delta_K}\dashrightarrow$ as in \cref{thm:lr-equivalence} and obtain
\begin{equation}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	K \& X \& Y \& {\,} \& K \& A \& B \& {\,} \\
	K \& 0 \& FK \& {\,} \& K \& 0 \& FK \& {\,}
	\arrow["i", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["f", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\boxed{\scriptstyle -i_\ast \delta_K}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["p", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["j", from=1-5, to=1-6]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["g", from=1-6, to=1-7]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-6, to=2-6]
	\arrow["{\boxed{\scriptstyle -j_\ast \delta_K}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=1-7, to=1-8]
	\arrow["q", from=1-7, to=2-7]
	\arrow[from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\delta_K}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["{\delta_K}", dashed, from=2-7, to=2-8]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}
			Here the natural isomorphism $\ell : \mathbb E(-,K) \simeq (-, FK)$ sends $\delta$ and $\varepsilon$ to $p$ and $q$ respectively. We show \cref{eq:hs-inde-ef-2}.

			We claim that $qv = p$. Note that
			\begin{equation}
				(qv)^\ast\delta_K = v^\ast (q^\ast \delta_K) = v^\ast \varepsilon = \delta = p^\ast\delta_K.
			\end{equation}
			Hence, $(qv-p)^\ast \delta_K = 0$. By \cref{thm:lr-equivalence}, we see $(qv-p) = 0$.\

			We then show that $q^\ast \eta = - i_\ast \varepsilon$. Here $\eta = i_\ast \delta_K$. A straightforward computation shows
			\begin{equation}
				q^\ast \eta = q^\ast (- i_\ast \delta_K) = - i_\ast (q^\ast \delta_K) = - i_\ast \varepsilon.
			\end{equation}
			We take $FK = C$.
		\end{proof}
	\end{proposition}

	\begin{theorem}\label{thm:hs-square-s}
		Given a homotopic square with a pair of parallel edges ($f,g$) in $S$, there is a way to complete the diagram
		\begin{equation}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	K \& X \& Y \& C \& {\,} \\
	K \& A \& B \& C \& {\,} \\
	\& {\boxed{\scriptstyle i_\ast l_g}} \& {\boxed{-\scriptstyle q^\ast r_f}} \& {\,}
	\arrow["i", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["f", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["u", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[""{name=0, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["p", from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["v", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{l_f}", dashed, from=1-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{r_f}", dashed, from=1-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["j", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["q", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{l_g}", dashed, from=2-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{r_g}", dashed, from=2-4, to=2-5]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[curve={height=6pt}, between={0.1}{1}, dotted, from=0, to=3-2]
\end{tikzcd},
		\end{equation}
		such that $(1_K;u;v)$ and $(u;v;1_C)$ are homotopic morphisms of conflations. Moreover, we can choose $F:\mathcal{L} \simeq \mathcal{R}$ as in \cref{thm:lr-equivalence,thm:rl-equivalence} so that
		\begin{equation}
			\ell (l_f) = p,\quad \ell (l_g) = q, \quad \rho (r_f) = - i,\quad \rho (r_g) = - j.
		\end{equation}
		\begin{proof}
			We complete the following diagram such that $(1_K;u;v)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations by \cref{prop:hs-inde-ef}:
			\begin{equation}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	K \& X \& Y \& {\,} \\
	K \& A \& B \& {\,}
	\arrow["i", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["f"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["u", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\boxed{\scriptstyle i_\ast l_g}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{l_f}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["v"', from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["j", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{l_g}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
			\end{equation}
			We define $p:= \ell^{-1}(l_f)$ and $q:= \ell^{-1}(l_g)$. Since $v^\ast l_g = l_f$, we see $qv = p$ by \cref{thm:lr-equivalence}. By construction, $r_f = - i_\ast \delta_K$ and $r_g = - j_\ast \delta_K$. Hence $\rho (r_f) = - i$ and $\rho (r_g) = - j$. Finally, we see
			\begin{equation}
				i_\ast l_g = i_\ast q^\ast \delta_K = q^\ast i_\ast \delta_K = - q^\ast r_f.
			\end{equation}
		\end{proof}
	\end{theorem}

\subsection{Snake lemmas}

\begin{theorem}\label{thm:snake-sss}
	Let $\alpha$, $\beta$, and $\gamma$ be both inflations and deflations, and $(\alpha; \beta; \gamma)$ be a homotopic morphism of conflations. Then there is a commutative diagram with dashed $z$
	
	\begin{equation}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, every matrix/.append style={name=myCD}]
	{K_\alpha} \& {K_\beta} \& {K_\gamma} \\
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
	\\
	L \& M \& N \& {\,} \\
	{C_\alpha} \& {C_\beta} \& {C_\gamma}
	\arrow["{f'}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g'}", from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["f", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\alpha"{pos=0.7}, from=2-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.7}, from=2-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma"{pos=0.7}, from=2-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow["u", from=4-1, to=4-2]
	\arrow[from=4-1, to=5-1]
	\arrow["v", from=4-2, to=4-3]
	\arrow[from=4-2, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=4-3, to=4-4]
	\arrow[from=4-3, to=5-3]
	\arrow["{u'}", from=5-1, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{v'}", from=5-2, to=5-3]
  % the new connecting arrow from K_gamma â†’ C_alpha:
\arrow[
  dashed,
  from=1-3,
  to=5-1,
  rounded corners,
  crossing over,
  to path={
    (myCD-1-3.east)
    -- ++(7ex,0)                % move right a bit
    -- ++(0,-5em)               % move down
    -- ++(-40ex,0)              % move left
    |- (myCD-5-1.west)          % then vertical+horizontal into the target west side
	node[pos=0.3, left] {z}  % add the label
  }
].
\end{tikzcd}
	\end{equation}
	such that any three terms in the mapping sequence
	\begin{equation}\label{eq:6-term-conflation-sequence}
		K_\alpha \xrightarrow{f'} K_\beta \xrightarrow{g'} K_\gamma \xrightarrow{z} C_\alpha \xrightarrow{u'} C_\beta \xrightarrow{v'} C_\gamma
	\end{equation}
	is an $\mathbb E$-conflation. Moreover, there is a way to take morphisms such that $K_\alpha \xrightarrow{f'} K_\beta \xrightarrow{g'} K_\gamma \overset{\ell^{-1}
	(z)}\dashrightarrow$, $K_\beta \xrightarrow{g'} K_\gamma \xrightarrow{z} C_\alpha \overset{- \ell^{-1}(u')}{\dashrightarrow}$, and $K_\gamma \xrightarrow{z} C_\alpha \xrightarrow{u'} C_\beta \overset{\ell^{-1}(v')}{\dashrightarrow}$ are $\mathbb E$-conflations.
	\begin{proof}
		We decompose the homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations $(\alpha; \beta; \gamma)$ into following diagrams:
\begin{equation}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{K_\alpha} \& {K_\alpha} \&\&\& L \& E \& Z \& {\,} \\
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \& L \& M \& N \& {\,} \\
	L \& E \& Z \& {\,} \&\& {C_\gamma} \& {C_\gamma} \\
	{\,} \& {\,} \&\&\&\& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_\alpha}"', from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{fi_\alpha}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["s", from=1-5, to=1-6]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["t", from=1-6, to=1-7]
	\arrow["{\beta_2}"', from=1-6, to=2-6]
	\arrow["{\boxed{\scriptstyle (p_\gamma)^\ast \eta_2}}"{description}, draw=none, from=1-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["\kappa", dashed, from=1-7, to=1-8]
	\arrow["\gamma"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-7, to=2-7]
	\arrow["f", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\alpha"'{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{\boxed{\scriptstyle (i_\alpha)_\ast\eta_1}}"{description}, draw=none, from=2-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\beta_1}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["u", from=2-5, to=2-6]
	\arrow["v", from=2-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["{p_\gamma v}"', from=2-6, to=3-6]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=2-7, to=2-8]
	\arrow["{p_\gamma}", from=2-7, to=3-7]
	\arrow["s", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{l_\alpha}"', dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["t", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\eta_1}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\kappa", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-6, to=3-7]
	\arrow["{\eta_2}"', dashed, from=3-6, to=4-6]
	\arrow["{r_\gamma}", dashed, from=3-7, to=4-7]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}
		Then $\beta_1$ and $\beta_2$ are both inflations and deflations by \cref{thm:hs-infdef}. By \cref{thm:hs-square-s}, we homotopic morphisms of conflations $(1;f;s)$, $(f;s;1)$, $(1;t;v)$ and $(t;v;1)$ as follows (dashed arrows indicate extension elements):
\begin{equation}\label{eq:snake-lem-steps}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{K_\alpha} \& X \& L \& {C_\alpha} \& {\,} \& {K_\gamma} \& E \& M \& {C_\gamma} \& {\,} \\
	{K_\alpha} \& Y \& E \& {C_\alpha} \& {\,} \& {K_\gamma} \& Z \& N \& {C_\gamma} \& {\,} \\
	\& {\boxed{\scriptstyle (i_\alpha)_\ast \eta_1}} \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle  -y^\ast r_\alpha}} \& {\,} \&\&\& {\boxed{\scriptstyle x_\ast l_\gamma}} \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle (p_\gamma)^\ast \eta_2}} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{i_\alpha}", from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["\alpha"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["f", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[""{name=0, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{p_\alpha}", from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["s", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{l_\alpha}", dashed, from=1-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{r_\alpha}", dashed, from=1-4, to=1-5]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-4, to=2-4]
	\arrow["x", from=1-6, to=1-7]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-6, to=2-6]
	\arrow["{\beta_2}", from=1-7, to=1-8]
	\arrow["t", from=1-7, to=2-7]
	\arrow[""{name=1, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-7, to=2-8]
	\arrow["{p_\gamma v}", from=1-8, to=1-9]
	\arrow["v", from=1-8, to=2-8]
	\arrow["{\mu_2}", dashed, from=1-8, to=2-9]
	\arrow["{\eta_2}", dashed, from=1-9, to=1-10]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-9, to=2-9]
	\arrow["{fi_\alpha}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\beta_1}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["y", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{\eta_1}", dashed, from=2-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{\mu_1}", dashed, from=2-4, to=2-5]
	\arrow["{i_\gamma}", from=2-6, to=2-7]
	\arrow["\gamma"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-7, to=2-8]
	\arrow["{p_\gamma}", from=2-8, to=2-9]
	\arrow["{l_\gamma}", dashed, from=2-8, to=3-9]
	\arrow["{r_\gamma}", dashed, from=2-9, to=2-10]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-7, to=3-8]
	\arrow[curve={height=6pt}, between={0.1}{1}, dotted, from=0, to=3-2]
	\arrow[curve={height=6pt}, between={0.1}{1}, dotted, from=1, to=3-7]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}
		We obtain $K_\alpha \xrightarrow{f'} K_\beta \xrightarrow{g'} K_\gamma \overset{x^\ast \eta_1}{\dashrightarrow}$ by \cref{prop:strict-et4-h}
\begin{equation}\label{eq:snake-sss-1}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{K_\alpha} \& {K_\beta} \& {K_\gamma} \& {\,} \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle (f')_\ast \eta_1}} \\
	{K_\alpha} \& Y \& E \& {\,} \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle (\beta_2)^\ast l_\beta}} \\
	\& M \& M \\
	\& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{f'}", dashed, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g'}", dashed, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{i_\beta}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[""{name=0, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{x^\ast \eta_1}", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow["x"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["{fi_\alpha}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\beta_1}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\beta", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\eta_1}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{\beta_2}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{l_\beta}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\mu_2}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow[curve={height=-6pt}, between={0.1}{1}, dotted, from=0, to=1-5]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}
We then construct $K_\beta \xrightarrow{\overline {g'}} K_\gamma \xrightarrow{z} C_\alpha \overset{\theta}{\dashrightarrow}$ by \cref{prop:po-2-h}
\begin{equation}\label{eq:snake-sss-2}
	% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{K_\beta} \& {K_\gamma} \& {C_\alpha} \& {\,} \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle (\beta_2)^\ast l_\beta}} \\
	Y \& E \& {C_\alpha} \& {\,} \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle -y^\ast \mu _1}} \\
	M \& M \\
	{\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{\overline {g'}}", dashed, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{i_\beta}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow[""{name=0, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "\square"{description}, draw=none, from=1-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["yx", dashed, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["x"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\theta", dashed, from=1-3, to=1-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-5, to=2-5]
	\arrow["{\beta_1}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\beta", from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["y", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{\beta_2}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\mu_1}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{l_\beta}", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["{\mu_2}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow[curve={height=-6pt}, between={0.1}{1}, dotted, from=0, to=1-5]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}
Recall that in our construction of \cref{prop:po-2-h}, $\overline {g'}$ can be any morphism such that $\boxed{\scriptstyle\beta_2^\ast l_\beta}$ is a homotopic square. Hence, we take $\overline {g'} = g'$. It remains to show $\ell (x^\ast \eta_1) = z$ here. Note that the construction in \cref{thm:hs-square-s} shows $\ell (\eta_1) = y$. Hence,
\begin{equation}
	\ell (x^\ast \eta_1) = \ell (\eta_1) x = y x = z.
\end{equation}

We next construct $K_\gamma \xrightarrow{z}C_\alpha \xrightarrow{u'} C_\beta \overset{\xi}\dashrightarrow$ by dual of \cref{prop:po-2-h}:
\begin{equation}\label{eq:snake-sss-3}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	\& Y \& Y \\
	{K_\gamma} \& E \& M \& {\, } \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle (\beta_1)_\ast r_\beta}} \\
	{K_\gamma} \& {C_\alpha} \& {C_\beta} \& {\,} \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle -x_\ast \xi}} \\
	\& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{\beta_1}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-3, to=1-2]
	\arrow["\beta", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["x", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{\beta_2}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["y"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow[""{name=0, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\mu_2}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{p_\beta}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-5, to=3-5]
	\arrow["yx", dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{u'}", dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{\mu_1}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\xi", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{r_\beta}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow[curve={height=-6pt}, between={0.1}{1}, dotted, from=0, to=2-5]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}

Recall that in our construction of \cref{prop:po-2-h}, $u'$ can be any morphism such that $\boxed{\scriptstyle -x_\ast \xi}$ is a homotopic square. We take $u' = \ell (\theta)$. Note that

\begin{enumerate}
	\item $u'y = \ell (y^\ast\theta) \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:snake-sss-2}}} - \ell (\beta_2^\ast l_\beta) = - \ell (l_\beta) \beta_2 \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:snake-lem-steps}}} p_\beta \beta_2$.
	\item $\mu_1 \xlongequal{\text{\cref{eq:snake-sss-2}}} (i_\beta)_\ast \theta = (i_\beta)_\ast \ell^{-1}(u') = \ell (F(i_\beta)u') = \ell (\ell^{-1}(r_\beta)u') = \ell \ell ^{-1}((u')^\ast r_\beta)= (u')^\ast r_\beta$.
	\item We claim that $E \xrightarrow{\binom{\beta_2}{-y}} M \oplus C_\alpha \xrightarrow{(p_\beta, u')}C_\beta \overset{(\beta_1)_\ast r_\beta}\dashrightarrow$ is an $\mathbb E$-conflation. Note that there are some $\mathbb E$-conflation $E \xrightarrow{\binom{\beta_2}{-y}} M \oplus C_\alpha \to C_\beta \dashrightarrow$, we see $\binom{\beta_2}{-y} \in S$ by \cref{prop:slr}. Hence, $\binom {\beta_2}{-y}$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation. By \cref{prop:po-2-h}, there is a dashed $\mathbb E$-conflation
	\begin{equation}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{K_\beta} \& {K_\beta} \\
	{K_\beta \oplus K_\beta} \& {Y\oplus K_\gamma} \& {M \oplus C_\alpha} \& {\,} \\
	{?} \& E \& {M \oplus C_\alpha} \& {\,} \\
	{\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{?}", dashed, from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{\binom {i_\beta}{g'}}", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{i_\beta \oplus g'}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{?}", dashed, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{\beta \oplus yx}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{(\beta_1,-x)}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{l_\beta \oplus \theta}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{?}", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{?}", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["{\binom{\beta_2}{-y}}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{(f')_\ast \eta_1}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{?}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation}
	Note that the top left morphism must be $\binom 1 1$, thus the left dashed $\mathbb E$-conflation splits. Note that 
	\begin{equation}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	{K_\beta} \& {K_\beta} \& {K_\beta} \\
	{K_\beta \oplus K_\beta} \& {K_\beta \oplus K_\beta} \& {Y\oplus K_\gamma} \& {M \oplus C_\alpha} \& {\,} \\
	{K_\beta} \& {\overline K_\beta } \& E \& {M \oplus C_\alpha} \& {\,} \\
	{\,} \& {\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow[equals, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow["{\binom 11}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow["{\binom 11}", dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\binom {i_\beta}{g'}}", from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{(1,-1)}", from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow["{i_\beta \oplus g'}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{?}", dashed, from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\beta \oplus yx}", from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["{(\beta_1,-x)}", from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{l_\beta \oplus \theta}", dashed, from=2-4, to=2-5]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-4, to=3-4]
	\arrow["\cong", from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\varphi }"', draw=none, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["{?}", from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["0", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{\binom{\beta_2}{-y}}", from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow["{(f')_\ast \eta_1}", dashed, from=3-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow["{?}", dashed, from=3-4, to=3-5]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation}
	By \cref{cor:five-lemma}, there is some isomorphism $\varphi$ making $(1_{K_\beta};1_{K_\beta \oplus K_\beta};\varphi)$ an isomorphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations. By diagram, the buttom row is the $\mathbb E$-conflation $K_\beta \xrightarrow{\beta_1 i_\beta} E \xrightarrow{\binom{\beta_2}{-y}} M \oplus C_\alpha \overset{(1,-1)_\ast (l_\beta\oplus \theta)}\dashrightarrow$. Note that $\ell ((1,-1)_\ast (l_\beta \oplus \theta)) = (\ell (l_\beta), -\ell (\theta)) = (p_\beta, u')$, and $\ell(\beta_1 i_\beta) = (\beta_1)_\ast \ell (i_\beta) = (\beta_1)_\ast r_\beta$. This proves the claim.
\end{enumerate}

We finally take the following diagram by \cref{prop:strict-et4-h}
\begin{equation}\label{eq:snake-sss-4}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&]
	Y \& Y \\
	E \& M \& {C_\gamma} \& {\,} \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle (\beta_1)_\ast r_\beta}} \\
	{C_\alpha} \& {C_\beta} \& {C_\gamma} \& {\,} \& {\boxed{\scriptstyle (v')^\ast \eta_2}} \\
	{\,} \& {\,}
	\arrow["{\beta_1}", from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow[equals, from=1-2, to=1-1]
	\arrow["\beta", from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow["{\beta_2}", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["y"{inner sep=.8ex}, "\bullet"{marking, text=\pgfkeysvalueof{/tikz/commutative diagrams/background color}}, "\circ"{marking}, from=2-1, to=3-1]
	\arrow[""{name=0, anchor=center, inner sep=0}, "\square"{description}, draw=none, from=2-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{p_\gamma v}", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["{p_\beta}", from=2-2, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\eta_2}", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-3, to=3-3]
	\arrow[equals, from=2-5, to=3-5]
	\arrow["{\overline {u'}}", dashed, from=3-1, to=3-2]
	\arrow["{\mu_1}", dashed, from=3-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["{v'}", dashed, from=3-2, to=3-3]
	\arrow["{r_\beta}", dashed, from=3-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["{y_\ast \eta_2}", dashed, from=3-3, to=3-4]
	\arrow[curve={height=-6pt}, between={0.1}{1}, dotted, from=0, to=2-5]
\end{tikzcd}.
\end{equation}
Recall that in our construction of \cref{prop:strict-et4-h}, $\overline {u'}$ can be any morphism such that $\boxed{\scriptstyle (\beta_1)_\ast r_\beta}$ is homotopic. Hence, we can take $\overline {u'} = u'$. A comparison of \cref{eq:snake-sss-3,eq:snake-sss-4} show that $v' = \ell (\xi)$.

This complete our verification.
	\end{proof}
\end{theorem}

We show some degenerate cases of \cref{thm:snake-sss}.

\begin{proposition}[\textbf{Case: S-?-S}]
	For $\alpha,\gamma \in S$ such that $(\alpha;\gamma)$ is a morphism of extensions, we can find $\beta \in S$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations. Moreover, we have the following commutative diagram with outer $6$-term $\mathbb E$-conflation 
	\begin{equation}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, every matrix/.append style={name=myCD}]
	{K_\alpha} \& {K_\beta} \& {K_\gamma} \\
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
	\\
	L \& M \& N \& {\,} \\
	{C_\alpha} \& {C_\beta} \& {C_\gamma}
	\arrow["{f'}", dashed, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g'}", dashed, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["f", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\alpha"{pos=0.7}, from=2-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.7}, dashed, from=2-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma"{pos=0.7}, from=2-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow["u", from=4-1, to=4-2]
	\arrow[from=4-1, to=5-1]
	\arrow["v", from=4-2, to=4-3]
	\arrow[dashed, from=4-2, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=4-3, to=4-4]
	\arrow[from=4-3, to=5-3]
	\arrow["{u'}", dashed, from=5-1, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{v'}", dashed, from=5-2, to=5-3]
  % the new connecting arrow from K_gamma â†’ C_alpha:
\arrow[
  dashed,
  from=1-3,
  to=5-1,
  rounded corners,
  crossing over,
  to path={
    (myCD-1-3.east)
    -- ++(7ex,0)                % move right a bit
    -- ++(0,-5em)               % move down
    -- ++(-40ex,0)              % move left
    |- (myCD-5-1.west)          % then vertical+horizontal into the target west side
	node[pos=0.3, left] {z}  % add the label
  }
]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation}
\end{proposition}

\begin{proposition}[\textbf{Case: S-S-?}]
	For $\alpha,\beta \in S$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;?)$ is a morphism of some $\mathbb E$-conflations, we can find $\gamma$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations. Moreover,
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item (Without WIC) $\gamma$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation, and we have the following commutative diagram with outer $5$-term $\mathbb E$-conflation:
		\item (Assume WIC) $\gamma \in S$, and we have the following commutative diagram with outer $6$-term $\mathbb E$-conflation:
	\end{enumerate}
	\begin{equation}
% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, every matrix/.append style={name=myCD}]
	{K_\alpha} \& {K_\beta} \& {K_\gamma} \\
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
	\\
	L \& M \& N \& {\,} \\
	{C_\alpha} \& {C_\beta} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,128;green,128;blue,128}{{C_\gamma}}
	\arrow["{f'}", dashed, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g'}", dashed, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["f", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\alpha"{pos=0.7}, from=2-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.7}, from=2-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma"{pos=0.7}, dashed, from=2-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow["u", from=4-1, to=4-2]
	\arrow[from=4-1, to=5-1]
	\arrow["v", from=4-2, to=4-3]
	\arrow[from=4-2, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=4-3, to=4-4]
	\arrow[dashed, from=4-3, to=5-3]
	\arrow["{u'}", dashed, from=5-1, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{v'}", color={rgb,255:red,128;green,128;blue,128}, dashed, from=5-2, to=5-3]
	  % the new connecting arrow from K_gamma â†’ C_alpha:
\arrow[
  dashed,
  from=1-3,
  to=5-1,
  rounded corners,
  crossing over,
  to path={
    (myCD-1-3.east)
    -- ++(7ex,0)                % move right a bit
    -- ++(0,-5em)               % move down
    -- ++(-40ex,0)              % move left
    |- (myCD-5-1.west)          % then vertical+horizontal into the target west side
	node[pos=0.3, left] {z}  % add the label
  }
]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation}
\end{proposition}

\begin{remark}
	\textbf{I-?-I} and \textbf{D-?-D} cases can be shown without WIC condition. \textbf{?-I-I} and \textbf{D-D-?} cases can be shown assuming WIC condition (in fact, they are equivalent coditions of WIC, \cref{thm:wic}).
\end{remark}

\begin{proposition}[\textbf{Case: I-S-?}]
	For $\alpha$ an $\mathbb E$-inflation and $\beta \in S$ such that such that $(\alpha;\beta;?)$ is a morphism of some $\mathbb E$-conflations, we can find $\gamma$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations. Moreover, 
	\begin{enumerate}
		\item (Without WIC) $\gamma$ is an $\mathbb E$-deflation, and we have the following commutative diagram with outer $5$-term $\mathbb E$-conflation:
		\item (Assume WIC) $\gamma \in S$, and we have the following commutative diagram with outer $5$-term $\mathbb E$-conflation:
	\end{enumerate}
	\begin{equation}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, every matrix/.append style={name=myCD}]
	\& {K_\beta} \& {K_\gamma} \\
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
	\\
	L \& M \& N \& {\,} \\
	{C_\alpha} \& {C_\beta} \& \textcolor{rgb,255:red,128;green,128;blue,128}{{C_\gamma}}
	\arrow["{g'}", dashed, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["f", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\alpha"{pos=0.7}, from=2-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.7}, from=2-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma"{pos=0.7}, dashed, from=2-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow["u", from=4-1, to=4-2]
	\arrow[from=4-1, to=5-1]
	\arrow["v", from=4-2, to=4-3]
	\arrow[from=4-2, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=4-3, to=4-4]
	\arrow[dashed, from=4-3, to=5-3]
	\arrow["{u'}", dashed, from=5-1, to=5-2]
	\arrow["{v'}", color={rgb,255:red,128;green,128;blue,128}, dashed, from=5-2, to=5-3]
  % the new connecting arrow from K_gamma â†’ C_alpha:
\arrow[
  dashed,
  from=1-3,
  to=5-1,
  rounded corners,
  crossing over,
  to path={
    (myCD-1-3.east)
    -- ++(7ex,0)                % move right a bit
    -- ++(0,-5em)               % move down
    -- ++(-40ex,0)              % move left
    |- (myCD-5-1.west)          % then vertical+horizontal into the target west side
	node[pos=0.3, left] {z}  % add the label
  }
]
\end{tikzcd}.
	\end{equation}
\end{proposition}

\begin{proposition}[\textbf{Case: S-D-?}]
	For $\alpha\in S$ and $\beta$ an $\mathbb E$-deflation such that such that $(\alpha;\beta;?)$ is a morphism of some $\mathbb E$-conflations, we can find some $\mathbb E$-deflation $\beta$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations. Moreover, we have the following commutative diagram with outer $4$-term $\mathbb E$-conflation:
	\begin{equation}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, every matrix/.append style={name=myCD}]
	{K_\alpha} \& {K_\beta} \& {K_\gamma} \\
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
	\\
	L \& M \& N \& {\,} \\
	{C_\alpha}
	\arrow["{f'}", dashed, from=1-1, to=1-2]
	\arrow[from=1-1, to=2-1]
	\arrow["{g'}", dashed, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["f", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\alpha"{pos=0.7}, from=2-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.7}, from=2-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma"{pos=0.7}, dashed, from=2-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow["u", from=4-1, to=4-2]
	\arrow[from=4-1, to=5-1]
	\arrow["v", from=4-2, to=4-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=4-3, to=4-4]
	  % the new connecting arrow from K_gamma â†’ C_alpha:
\arrow[
  dashed,
  from=1-3,
  to=5-1,
  rounded corners,
  crossing over,
  to path={
    (myCD-1-3.east)
    -- ++(7ex,0)                % move right a bit
    -- ++(0,-5em)               % move down
    -- ++(-40ex,0)              % move left
    |- (myCD-5-1.west)          % then vertical+horizontal into the target west side
	node[pos=0.3, left] {z}  % add the label
  }
]
\end{tikzcd}
	\end{equation}
\end{proposition}

There is also a twist case for $3 \times 3$ lemma.

\begin{proposition}[\textbf{Case: I-D-?}]
	For $\alpha$ and $\mathbb E$-inflation and $\beta$ an $\mathbb E$-deflation such that such that $(\alpha;\beta;?)$ is a morphism of some $\mathbb E$-conflations, we can find retract of some $\mathbb E$-deflation $\beta$ such that $(\alpha;\beta;\gamma)$ is a homotopic morphism of $\mathbb E$-conflations. Moreover, we have the following commutative diagram with outer $\mathbb E$-conflation:
	\begin{equation}
		% https://q.uiver.app/#
\begin{tikzcd}[ampersand replacement=\&, every matrix/.append style={name=myCD}]
	\& {K_\beta} \& {K_\gamma} \\
	X \& Y \& Z \& {\,} \\
	\\
	L \& M \& N \& {\,} \\
	{C_\alpha}
	\arrow["{g'}", dashed, from=1-2, to=1-3]
	\arrow[from=1-2, to=2-2]
	\arrow[dashed, from=1-3, to=2-3]
	\arrow["f", from=2-1, to=2-2]
	\arrow["\alpha"{pos=0.7}, from=2-1, to=4-1]
	\arrow["g", from=2-2, to=2-3]
	\arrow["\beta"{pos=0.7}, from=2-2, to=4-2]
	\arrow["\delta", dashed, from=2-3, to=2-4]
	\arrow["\gamma"{pos=0.7}, dashed, from=2-3, to=4-3]
	\arrow["u", from=4-1, to=4-2]
	\arrow[from=4-1, to=5-1]
	\arrow["v", from=4-2, to=4-3]
	\arrow["{\varepsilon }", dashed, from=4-3, to=4-4]
		  % the new connecting arrow from K_gamma â†’ C_alpha:
\arrow[
  dashed,
  from=1-3,
  to=5-1,
  rounded corners,
  crossing over,
  to path={
    (myCD-1-3.east)
    -- ++(7ex,0)                % move right a bit
    -- ++(0,-5em)               % move down
    -- ++(-40ex,0)              % move left
    |- (myCD-5-1.west)          % then vertical+horizontal into the target west side
	node[pos=0.3, left] {z}  % add the label
  }
]
\end{tikzcd}
	\end{equation}
\end{proposition}
